At-a-Glance: Match treatment to brood status, temperature, and residue risk. Rotate actives to reduce resistance.
Why it Matters: Effective control with minimal taint and resistance pressure.
Protects winter bees and harvest reputation.
Objectives: Keep a rotation plan across seasons.
Tie each product to a clear SOP and timing window.
Verify efficacy and record all batches.
What Good Looks Like: Decision matrix: season × brood × temperature → option list.
Boxes and honey flows scheduled to avoid conflicts.
Step-by-Step: 1) Identify window: pre/post harvest, broodless vs brood-on.
2) Select active: oxalic, formic, thymol, amitraz—per label and plan.
3) Prepare kit and safety gear; apply per SOP.
4) Recount mites; document efficacy; rotate actives next time.
Seasonality & Climate: Cold broodless midwinter suits oxalic dribbles/vapor where legal.
Warm late summer suits thymol/formic—respect temp limits.
Data & Thresholds: Temperature bands from labels guide go/no-go.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Symptom: Low efficacy -> Reassess application; reinvasion; change active.
Symptom: Bee stress -> Check temperature and ventilation; stop if unsafe.
Symptom: Residue worry -> Use non-taint options outside supers; observe withdrawal.
Common Pitfalls: Treating during nectar flow with tainting actives.
Poor ventilation on formic leading to queen loss.
Tools & Techniques: Timers, PPE, applicators/vaporizers, spacers for ventilation.
Safety & Compliance: Follow labels and local approvals strictly.
PPE and ventilation especially for acids and vapours.
Communications: Explain rotation to club mates to reduce resistance pressure.
Notes: Schedule treatments on the calendar the day you add supers to avoid clashes later.
